div3.p: --A for sale at low price

div3.head:
Glorious News!
the Confederate army victorious at Corinth.
div3.p:
--A great battle took place above Corinth, thing morning.
Our soldiers attacken and fought the Federals with immense bravery and violence, and drove them back with great slaughter.
They captured eight batteries and many prisoners.
The enemy's whole army was engaged.
Gen. Gladden lost his left arm.

Authentic information received this evening says that we shall destroy or capture the Federal force.
No further particulars.

div3.head: From Island no.10.
div3.p:
--A special dispatch to the New Orleans Picayune, from Memphis, dated 4th, says that a very severe storm occurred at Fort Pillow and Island No.10 on Tuesday night last.
The steamer Kanawha Valley was capsized and wrecked, and the men on board floated down towards New Madrid, but were saved by the steamers De Seto and Grampus.
Many were without clothes.
They arrived on the Scotland.

The shelling of Island No.10 continues without effect.
One of the enemy's gunboats and one transport have been badly injured.
No further movements above.
The enemy have abandoned Union City.

div3.head: From Tennessee river.
div3.p:
--A general engagement is expected daily in Tennessee.
Orders have been given to clear the hospitals and prepare for the reception of the wounded.
Gen. Buell is reported to be near the eastern shore of Tennessee river, in conjunction with a column from Nashville.
The Confederates are rapidly concentrating, and are confident of victory.

div3.head: From Pass Christian.
div3.p: --The operator at Pass Christian telegraphed this morning as follows:

q.p:
"The enemy shelled Pass Christian yesterday, landed 2,400 troops, and attacked us with 2,000 men and twelve 24-pounder howitzers.
Our force was 300 men and two 6 pounder howitzers.
I was in the fight and had a narrow escape."

div3.p:
A Meeting of-the Ladies' Defence Association will be held at the Broad street Methodist Church, (Rev. Dr. Doggett's,) on Monday, the 7th At 4½ o'clock in the afternoon, at which time Capt. Maury will deliver an address, and Commander Farrand will make such statements and specifications as will give a clear view of the objects of the Associations.
A full meeting of the members is requested, and of all persons favorable to this important move.
Gentlemen are invited to be present
By order of the President and Board of Directors.

div3.head: Union prayer Meeting.
div3.p: --A Union Prayer Meeting, under the of the Young Men's Christian the Div blessing upon our Confederacy, will be held every Evening, Sunday, this week at the Second Baptist, Church, (Seeby's,) corner of 6th and streets, at 5 o'clock.
Pastors and congregations, and in the city, are invited to attend and participate in the meetings.

Dr. Parker takes pleasure in recommending Dr. Coggin to his friends and patrons.

div3.head:
Headq'rs Dep't of Henrico.
Richmond, Va., March 31, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, no. 12.

list.item:
I. Huckstering in the markets of this city is so great an evil, that it has become necessary to abate it. The whole system is therefore abolished.the practice of purchasing produce on its way to market is prohibited; persons found buying or selling in such case, within ten years of Richmond, are liable to punishment at the discretion of a court-martial, and the produce will be forfeited to the person informing against the offenders.
The Provost Marshal will give every assistance to the clerks of the markets in enforcing the city Ordinance regulating this subject, and police officers under his direction will attend the markets for such purpose.
All purchaser at wholesale in the markets until after the regular market hours is forbidden.
Persons found sleeping in the markets will be arrested and punished by a court-martial.This order will go into immediate operation.No hindrance whatever will be off red to country persons bringing produce to this market, but every facility afforded for the accomplishment of such purpose.

II.
the following tariff of maximum prices is established for the sale of produce in the markets, and none other will be permitted this tariff to go into operation on and after Monday, 7th of April, 1862,

div3.closer:
By order of Brig Gen. John H. Winder,
L. R. Page, Assistant
Adjutant General. ap 1--1w

div3.head:
Hdq'rs Crutchfield Light Artillery,
March 13th, 1862.
div3.p: Attention, Volunteers!
Battery secured.

The undersigned, having secured a splendid Battery of field-pieces, have authority to raise a company of Light Artillery, to be mustered in the Provisional Army of Virginia for the war, and have received authority from the Governor to recruit volunteers from the Militia, to fill the ranks of the Crutchfield Light Artillery.
The company will be mustered in as soon as a sufficient number of volunteers have been received.
A fine opportunity now presents itself to those who do not wish to go as militiamen, to enroll themselves as volunteers.
No substitutes received.
Apply at the office of the Old Dominion Insurance Company under the St. Charles Hotel.

div3.head:
War Department,
Dj't and Insp. General's Office,
Richmond March 29th, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No. 18.

list.item: I. The following Proclamation is published for the information of all concerned:Proclamation:"By virtue of the power vested in me by law to declare the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus:"I, Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederate States of America coproclaim that martial law is hereby extended over the counties of Green brier, Pocahontas, Bath, Allegheny, Monroe, Mercer, Raleigh, Fayette, Nicholas, and Randolph; and I do proclaim the suspension of all civil jurisdiction, (with the exception of that enabling the Courts to take cognizance of the probate of wills, the administration of the estate of deceased dersons, the qualification of guardians, to enter decrease and orders for the partition and sale of property, to make orders concerning roads and bridges, to arose county levies and to order the payment of county dues) and the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus in the counties aforesaid."In faith whereof I have hereunto signed my name and set my seal this 29th day of March, in the year one thousand eight hundred and sixty-two[Signed] Jefferson Davis."

II. Brig-Gen. Henry Beth is charged with the due execution of the foregoing Proclamation.--He will forthwith establish an efficient military police, and will enforce the following orders: All distillation of spirituous liquors is positively prohibited and the distilleries will forthwith be closed.
The sale of spirituous liquors of any kind is also prohibited, and establishments for the sale thereof will be closed.

III.
All persons infringing the above prohibition, will suffer such punishment as shall be ordered by the sentence of a court-martial, provided that no sentence to hard labor for more than one month shall be inflicted by the sentence of a Regimental Court-Martial, as directed by the 67th Article of War.

div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
[Signed] S. Cooper,
Adj't and Inspector General. mh 31--6t

M., the following valuable real estate; Lots Nos 40, 41, and 42, in Graham's Plan, fronting 486 feet on the west line of Bacon street, running back about 320 feet to Bacon's branch, having thereon a large framed dwelling, (now occupied by Mr. Irving,) and a large number of other publicings, suitable for the slaughtering business Also, Lot No. 46, fronting 100 feet on the west side of Brook road, running back 280 feet to Bacon street, and having a front of 100 feet on Mr. Wm. Sledd on the north, and Mr. Peter Lawson on the south.
This is a most valuable building site.

The taxes for 1862 to be paid by the purchasers.

It is admirably arranged for a store below and dwelling above, and is now in perfect repair in every respect.
It can be rented to a good tenant at an annual rent or $950.

Terms.--Half cash; balance at 12 months, for negotiable notes, interest added.
secured by a trust deed.
The taxes for 1862 to be paid by the purchaser.

It is proverbial for its healthiness, and the road to it is a most excellent one.

The is to well known that a particular is deemed necessary.
There is about two hundred acres of is good and one hundred acres in wood and timber There is on the place buildins suitable for the accommodation of two separate families and houses.
If desired the place will be subdivided to suit the vies of The neighborhood is amongst the best in the county, and the place It is only necessary to examine the premises to be pleased with them.
After the sale of the land, all the personal affects on the place will be said, consisting of mules hogs, corn, farming &c.

div3.head:
[correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.]
Gen. McClellan's and nephew-- remarkable
liberality — free Market — things about Mobile.
div3.p:
A few days since Mr. English, sister of Gen. McClellan, the Yankee Commander-in-Chief, was in this city, and of course attracted some attention.
Her husband is a wealthy planter, and lives just above this on the Alabama river.
Young English, the General's nephew, has gone up to Corinth to fight for the South.
He seems to desire nothing so much as to most in house, a combat his distinguished kinsman.

By the way, Abe' Lincoln's wife has two sisters living not far from McClellan's sister, on this same beautiful river.
How strange that the Lincolnites should insist on bringing "fire and the sword" against these so near to them by the line of blood.

I venture the assertion that no city in the Confederacy has evinced greater literality signs this war has been upon us than Mobile Everybody belongs to some society whose object is to believe the poor families of the volunteers, or in some other way to aid the great cause.
The men lay down their thousands while the poor give hundreds out of their earnings.
Five thousand dollars a month in given to keeping up the free market, and this is but one of the items.
Thousands here are thrown out of employment, and are cared by those in better circumstances.

I dare not write you all that would be of interest to regard to the situation of things here.
Suffice it to say, that forces are pouring in from the interior and that the enemy has disappeared.
Mobile will be held at all hazard and to the last extremity, and if the enemy ever name in possession of it it will be through "much tribulation" *

div3.head:
[correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.]
great Freshes — Damages — War
div3.p:
Never to the memory of man has there been such a teacher in this region, is within a few weeks past.
The Alabama river have so the region foreign which to flows for that whole plantations are submerged.--For some days it has been impossible to tell where the channel of the river to, so that to-day, in coming up from Mobile, I saw the Jeff Davis, a fine steamer, in the corn field some distance from the river having affect over trees, cank, and . Many firm houses are being swept off, and I presume many will take their steps, forming a .

The war spirit is surging, and dashing, and sweeping everything before it, even to the coming waters of the Alabama.--The people are just as and determined as they were when the war over Manasses, Leesburg, and other victories.
Now it is a and more than like .

This is truly a patriotic old county.
She has now in the field river to of population.
Her laid their lives upon the alter at Freedom, and should these she has others ready to take their places.

The volunteers from Parson have and much.
Two companies (Capt. Harris's and Capt.) were exposed to the toils and of Western Virginia.
Many are now lying buried in that mountain and country.
Tence to their ashes, rest in their . The patriotism of did much to alleviate their sufferings, by sending them provisions, clothing, &c. The Generality of old Person was never more highly appreciated than by my company a few days ago.

In the disastrous retreat from Newborn, on the 14th, everything but what we had on. No sooner did our friends in Person wear of our distribution, than they ministered to our wants by sending us clothing, blankets, . How thankful were we to receive them.
We had been lying for several days (on the ground) without tents or blankets, exposed to the cold and rain.
But now we have clothing and blankets, and other things needful for our comfort.
To the liberality of our friends in Person are we indebted for these things.
Then, on behalf of my company, I would my thanks to all those who contributed on our relief, and especially to the fair at home, (had alert them.) They are always foremost in noble deeds.
With such friends at home to sympathize with and to aid us, we shall never give up (God being our helper,) until every Yankee is driven from our soil.

Carriages!
Carriages!! Carriages!!!
div3.p:
--The subscriber intends giving up his state house by the 1st of May, and will offer for sale his stock of Rockawave, Buggies with and without tops, and Spring Wagons, which have been put up with great this market at very low prices.
As he intends to and every vehicle on hand, he could further state that all persons in want of Carriages, &c., will find it greatly to their advantage to give him a call, as he is determined to sell in order to close out the stock.

div3.head:
C. S. Of America,
War Dep't. Ordnance Office, Richmond, March 3, 1862.
div3.p: Bills will be received at this Office until the 16th day of April next, for the following Ordnance and Ordnance Material for the Confederate States army:

list.item: 200,000 tons charcoal cold blast Pig Iron, (40,000 tons of Blooms, charcoal,)
60,000 tons Wrought Iron Bars, of various sizes,

div3.p: Bills may be made for any quantity of iron over one hundred tons, and for any number of guns over ten.
Drawings of the guns will be furnished only in portion whose are accepted.
Holders will state the points of delivery, and the date at which are less than one hundred tons of iron may be expected to be furnished.
They must also state the required to furnish the whole of their bid.
Bidders for guns will state the date of the first delivery, and the time required to supply the whole number.
Payments will be made for delivery of not less than fifty tons of iron, and the right to pay one-half in Confederate bonds is reserved.
Bids must be sealed and enclosed, and enveloped on the envelope "Proposals for Iron, " or "Proposals for Guns," as the case may be.

Gorgas, Lieutenant-Colonel, Chief of Ordnance, The following papers will please insert the above advertisement till 10th April, and send duplicate with copy of paper to Ordnance Office for settlement.
The Richmond Inquirer, Whig and Dispatch, Lynchburg Republican, Staunton Spectator, Abingdon Virginian; Petersburg Express, Raleigh (N. C.) Register; Wilmington (N. C.) Journal, Charlotte (N. C.) Bullitin; Charleston (S. C.) Mercury and Courier; Columbia (S. C.) South Carolinian; Augusta (Ga.) Savannah (Ga.) Republican; Columbia (Ga.) Times; Atlanta (Ga.) Confederacy; Rome (Ga.) one paper; Tallahassee (Fla.) Floridian; Huntsville, (Alabama,) one paper; Montgomery (Alabama,) Advertiser and Mail; Mobile (Alabama,) Register; (ala.) one paper; Knoxville (Tennessee,) Register; Memphis (Tenn.) Appeal; New Orleans (La.) Bullitin; Picayune, Delta, and Crescent; Jackson (Miss.) Mississippian; Corinth, (Miss.) one paper; Little Rock (Ark.) Gazette; Austin (Texas) Gazette; Galleston (Texas) Herald.

div3.head: By Goddin & Apperson, Auctioneers.
div3.p:
Receiver's Sale of Valuable Real estate in Henrico county two miles below Richmond, on the New Williamsburg Turnpike.--By virtue of a decree of the District Court of the Confederate States of America, in the case of the Confederate States of America against Charles Seiffert, on a petition to sequestrate the property of Lewis Tudor, I shall proceed to sell at public auction, on the premises, in the order advertised, on Tuesday, the 15th April, 1862, at 1 ½ o'clock P. M., the following valuable Real Estate, viz: 1st.
The neat Cottage Farm, about 4½ miles below Richmond, adjoining the lands of Messrs. John Poe and Chas. B. Williams, containing a acres, recently occupied by said Tudor.
2d.
The valuable tract of land about 2 miles from Richmond, adjoining Hughes's tavern, containing -1000 acres. Both of these places are located on said Williamsburg turnpike, and in a most improving part of the county.
At the same and place, will be sold two horses and some personal effects.

Terms--Cash as to the personal property.
As to the real estate 4th cash; balance at 6, 12 and 18 months, bonds bearing interest, with good security, and title retained till the last payment is made.
The taxes for 1862 to be paid by the purchaser.

Beautiful and highly Attractive Real estate, on Church Hill, on Marshall, Broad, and Grace streets, for sale at Auction.--Will be sold at auction, on the premises, in the order advertised, on Friday, the 11th April, 1862, at 12 o'clock M., that beautiful square of land on which Mr. Thomas Nowland now resides, bounded by Broad, Marshall, 27th, and 28th streets, having a front of 264 feet on each of the two former streets.
It will be subdivided into smaller lots of suitable size, according to a plat and survey, to be seen at the hour of sale, each lot running back 155 feet to a 20 foot alley.
On this square there stands a very large and well-built Brick Dwelling, which, by being repaired, could be made a most desirable residence.

After the sale of this square, will be sold a most beautiful Lot on the north side of Grace, between 28th and 29th streets, adjoining the two new brick tenements recently erected by Mr. George Turner, fronting 77 feet, running back 140 feet to an alley 15 feet wide.

Terms--One third cash; balance at 1 and 2 years, for negotiable notes, interest payable annually, secured by a trust deed.
The taxes for 1862 to be paid by the purchaser.

Excellent Framed Tenement, on the West line of 25TH St., opposite to the Leigh street Baptist Church, for Sale at Auction.--Immediately after the foregoing sale, will be sold that excellent framed Dwelling, located as above, now in the occupancy of Mr. Roberts.
It has every convenience for a moderate sized family.
Terms--As above.

Two half Acre Lots, bounded by 27TH and 28TH, and sts., Church Hill, for Sale at Auction.--Immediately after the foregoing sale, will be sold those two beautiful half-acre Lots, located as above, to be divided into lots to suit bidders.
Terms--as above.

50 Lots in the plan of "Griffin's Spring," and A large number of other Lots, some on Lester street, some in Fulton and some in Port Mayo, for Sale at Auction.--Will be sold at auction, on the premises, on Wednesday, the 9th April, 1862, commencing at 11 o'clock A. M., about 50 Lots, in the plan of "Griffin's Spring" property, having fronts on each side of a continuation of Main st., and with a three hundred yards of the Eastern corporation line.
A plat of the Lots can be seen at our office.
After which will be sold a valuable Lot on the east line of Lester street, near to Nicholson st., fronting 50 feet running back 614 feet.

Also five beautiful Lots in Fulton, in Square No. 7, each fronting the 20 feet on the south side of Nicholson street, and three Lots in Square No. 5, each fronting 30 feet on the south side of Graham street.
Also, several beautiful Lots in Port Mayo, adjoining the grocery store of Mr. Timothy Kerse, also, Mr. Kerse's excellent store and dwelling.
The foregoing real estate presents an excellent opportunity for persons to invest their surplus funds in real estate.

Term--One-third cash; balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes interest added, secured by a trust deed, or like retained.
The taxes for 1862 to be paid by the purchasers.

Neat and very DESIRABLYLocated Residence, on the West Line of Fifth, between Main and Cary Streets, for Sale at Auction.--Will be sold at auction, on the premises, on Thursday, the 10th April, 1862, at 4 o'clock P. M., the neat and very desirably situated Residence, located as above, now in the occupancy of Mr. Francis T. Glasgow, and opposite the residence of the late James Scott, Esq. The Lot house front of feet, and a depth of 120 feet, to a wide alley.
The dwelling has six rooms, besides brick- Kitchen, and large new brick Stable and Carriage House.
The location is amongst the best in Richmond.

Terms.--One-third cash; balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, secured by a trust deed.

div3.head: Valuable Farm of 308 acres, in Henrico county, on the Quiocison Road, 7 miles West of Richmond, for Sale at Auction.
div3.p:
--Will be sold at auction, on the premises, on Thursday, the 10th April, 1862, at 11 o'clock A. M., that valuable and highly improved Farm, located as above, (recently owned by Mr. B. W. Green,) called Guy's, containing 398 acres, according to a survey to be exhibited at the hour of sale.
It lies opposite to the residence of Mr. R. D. Carter, and adjoins the place on which Mr. Green now resides.
The land, for the most part, is highly improved.
The buildings on the place are to such an estate.
The land lays beautifully, and the crops now on it will indicate the fertility of the soil.

Terms.--One-third cash; balance at one and two years, for negotiable notes, interest added, payable half yearly, secured by a trust deed.
The taxes for 1862 to be paid by the purchaser.

div3.head: Most Valuable and well locatedprivate Residence on the East line of Governor street, for Sale at Auction.
div3.p:
--Will be sold at auction, on the premises, on Wednesday, the 9th April, 1862, at 1 ½ o'clock P. M., either of those two remarkably well-built and admirably-located Tenements, on the east line of Governor street, occupied the one by Dr. W. D. P. the other by George W. Johnson, Esq., the purchaser to have choice of tenements.
A single bid will be reserved by the owner, in order to prevent a sacrifices; and the selected by the purchaser is to be sold subject to the rights of the These tenements were built about ten years ago, under the superintendence of Mr. Henry Fixall, and no expense was spared to make them as perfect and durable in every respect as was practicable.
They are so well and favorably known (and being on Governor street, opposite the Governor's Mansion,) that a more general description is deemed unnecessary.
They have all the usual accommodations for a first class dwelling, and are believed to be in excellent order.

Terms--One-fourth cash; balance at 6, 12 and 18 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, secured by a trust deed.
The taxes and insurance for 1862 to be paid by the purchaser.

div3.head: Two most Valuable stores andDwellings on the South side of Broad third and Fourth streets, for Sale at Auction.
div3.p: --Will be sold at auction, on the premises, on Tuesday, the 8th April, 1862, at 4½ o'clock P. M., those two remarkably well built and admirably well arranged granite and iron front tenements located as above, one of which is now in the occupancy of Mr. Thomas D Quarles, and the other recently in the occupancy of Messrs. Crenshaw, Quarles & Co.

The tenement occupied by Mr. Quarles is a very large one, and is not only admirably well adapted to a Dry Goods Store, but the upper part is among the most convenient and well arranged for the accommodation of a large family to be found on Broad street.
The tenement recently occupied by Messrs. Crenshaw, Quarles & Co. is generally conceded is Dry Goods Store in this city.

Terms--One-third cash; balance at one and two years, for negotiable notes, (interest payable half-yearly) secured by a trust deed, with privilege to the purchaser to anticipate the credit payments.
The taxes and insurance for 1862 to be paid by the purchasers.

div3.head: Very excellent and well located private Dwelling, on the North side of Leigh, between 8th and 9th streets, for Sale at Auction.
div3.p:
--We will sell at auction, on the premises, on Thursday, the 10th April, 1862; at 4 ½ o'clock P. M., that large and well-built Brick Tenement located as above, now in the occupancy of Mr. Fred W. Pleasants, and adjoining the residence of Mr. Geo. W. Gretter.
The house is in excellent order; has ten rooms and the usual servants' accommodations; is supplied with gas and water, and is, altogether, a first-class dwelling.
The neighborhood and location is a very desirable one, and quite convenient to all the usual places of business.

Terms.--One-third cash; balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, secured by a trust deed.
The taxes and insurance for 1862 to be paid by the purchaser.

div3.head: By Goddin & Apperson, Auctioneers.
div3.p:
Valuable Real estate on the West line of 10th, Between Main and Cary Streets, for Sale at Auction.--Will be sold at auction on the premises, on Monday, the 14th April, 1862, at 1 o'clock P. M., the excellent Brick Tenement located as above, now in the occupancy of Dr. Patrick Cullen.
The lot has a front of 26½ feet, and a depth of 25 ½ feet, and bounded on the south by a 20 foot alley.
The location is a most valuable one for business purposes.
Possession given 1st May next.

Terms.--One-third cash; balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, secured by a trust deed.
The taxes and insurance for 1862 to be paid by the purchaser.

The Valuable Farm called "Cedar Hill." Three and a Half Miles East of Richmond, Containing 325 Acres, Together with Personal Effects Thereon, For Sale at Auction.--At the request of Charles Y. Morriss, Esq., we shall sell at auction, on the premises, on Tuesday, the 8th April, 1862, at 11 o'clock A. M., the valuable Farm located as above, containing 325 acres, adjoining the lands of Dr. Wm. A. Christian, Dr. John N. Friend, and Col. Sherwin McRae.
The improvements consist of a dwelling, containing five rooms, a stable, corn house, tobacco-houses, and other out-buildings.
About 100 acres in high land, well set in clover; about 100 acres in pine and oakwood of original growth, which will yield, it is said, about 60 cords per acre.
The remaining 125 acres is in Chickahominy low grounds, on which about 100 bushels winter oats have been seeded.
The location is a very healthy one, and the neighborhood unexceptionable.
Immediately after the sale of the land, all the personal effects on the same will be sold, consisting of corn, fodder, shucks, straw, wagons, carts, mules, horses, and farming implements.
Possession given at once, if required.

Terms.--For the real estate, one-third cash; balance at 1 and 2 years, for bonds, bearing interest, secured by a trust deed.
For the personal effects, all sums under $100 cash, over that amount, 4 months credit, for approved endorsed negotiable paper.

div3.head: Ten beautiful Lots on the North side of Grace street, between Belviders and Henry streets, for Sale at Auction.
div3.p:
--Will be sold at auction on the premises, on Friday, the 11th April, 1862, at 4½ o'clock P. M., ten beautiful lots, in Morton's Garden, located as above, each having a front of thirty feet, and a depth of one hundred and fifty feet to a twenty-foot alley.
These lots are well enclosed, and have fine shade trees in front, and are most beautiful for genteel residences to be built on.

Terms.--One-third cash; balance at one and two years, for negotiable notes, interest payable half yearly, secured by a trust deed.
The taxes for 1862 to be paid by the purchasers.

div3.head: By Kent, Paine &Co., Auctioneers.
div3.p:
Dry Goods at Auction — large and Peremptory Sale of Stable and Fancy Dry Goods by Catalogue.--On Tuesday, the 8th instant, commencing at 10 o'clock, at our warehouse, we shall sell by catalogue, a large and desirable assortment of Seasonable Goods, just received from an extensive importing and jobbing house, and a splendid lot of fine Fancy Goods, from a large Southern retail house declining business; together comprising one of the largest and most attractive assortments ever offered for sale in this market.
As our orders are imperative to sell the goods, they will be sold without limit or reserve.
Kent, Paine & Co., Auct's.

div3.head:
By Redwood & Keach, Auctioneers,
[51 Main Street.]
div3.p:
Sale of one-half of Schooner Wm. E. Furguson at Auction.--By request of the parties concerned, we will sell at public auction, on Monday, 14th day of April, 1862, at 4 o'clock P. M., at the foot of 17th street, on the Dock, one-half of the Schooner Wm. E. Furguson.
Also, at the same time on Anchor.

div3.head: By Dunlop, Moncure &Co., Aucts.
div3.p: Sugar, Coffee, Molasses, &c., at Auction.--On Tuesday, the 8th inst., commencing at 10½ o'clock, we will sell at our auction store--
50 bhds. Sugar, ranging from fair to choice quality.
75 bags Rio and Cuba Coffee.
20 bbls Molasses.
20 sacks Salt.
Pepper, Ginger, Pimento, &c.

Terms--Cash.
Sale without regard to weather.
Dunlop, Moncure & Co.,
Auctioneers.
Additional — Will be added to the above sale--
40 boxes assorted Candy,
75 bags Dried Peaches,
140 boxes Saleratus.

div3.head: Executor's Sale of Valuable property.
div3.p: --In pursuance of the will of the late Dr. Charles Minor, I will offer for sale, on the premises on Tuesday, the 25th day of April next, or if that be not fair, on the next fair day thereafter, the valuable estate called Brookhill, on which the deceased resided at the time of his death.

It lies in the county of Albemarle, six miles North of Charlottesville, on the south branch of the Rivanna river, and contains by recent survey 577½ acres, of which a due proportion is in limber.--From 80 to 90 acres are river low grounds of the best quality, well drained, and highly productive.
The uplands are fertile, and the whole farm is in good condition.
So much of it (including a large part of the low grounds) is in grass toat, with a favorable season, it is compated the hay-crop this year will not be short of 200,000 pounds. A manufacturing and saw mill are just at the gate, and blacksmith's and wheelwright shops close by.--The social advantages of the neighborhood, in point of refinement, intelligences, and virtue are nowhere excelled, besides the easy access to Charlottesville.
It would be a good location for a physician, and in quiet times for a school.

The improvements consist of a two-story dwelling house of brick, with nine rooms, besides basement, dining room, four frame out-houses, containing upwards of 20 lodging rooms, adapted to a boys' school, for which their were designed and have been used, and the usual offices, servants' houses, harps, stables, &c.

I propose to sell at the same time all the household and kitchen furniture belonging to the estate of the deceased, including all the appliances requisite for a large boarding school.
Amongst other things may be mentioned a quantity of blankets and bedding, stoves, chairs, benches, desks, &c., an excellent Rosewood Piano, fine carpets, a carriage, two-horse buggy, and spring wagon, and also a series of the best German and American school maps, on rollers, as good as new, and a large and well selected library, professional and general.

I propose at the same time to offer several valuable negroes, of both sexes, and the farm-stock and utensils, together with the stocks of bacon, corn, hay, and other forage, so that the purchaser of the farm may provide himself abundantly with all that he needs to conduct it.

Terms.--For the land, one-half cash; the remainder in two and four years, with interest from the day of sale, secured by good personal security, and a deed of trust on the premises.
For the personal property, all sums under $20 cash; over that amount, a credit of four months, with interest added, secured by negotiable note, well endorsed.
Proposals to purchase privately before the day of sale may be made to me at the University of Virginia, or to Franklin Minor, Esq., in Richmond, during the sitting of the Legislature.
The land will be shown to any one wishing to inspect it, by Mr. Marsh, the overseer.
div3.closer:
John B. Minor,
Acting Ex'r of Chas. Minor, dec'd.
The above sale is postponed until Wednesday, the 8th day of May, (if fair; if not, until the next fair day.)
J. B. M. ap 5--tds

div3.head: Household and Kitchen Furniture at Auction.
div3.p: --With a view of discontinuing housekeeping I will sell at my residence, near to Hubard's Foundry, on the Grove Road, on Tuesday, the 8th day of April, commencing at 10 o'clock, my entire Household and Kitchen Furniture, consisting of the usual variety of select articles, all in good order.
Terms--Cash on delivery.

div3.head: Administratrix's Sale of Real estate, &c., in Chesterfield county.
div3.p:
--Will be sold on the premises, on Thursday, the 17th day of April next, (if fair; if not, the next fair day,) a tract of land called "Chesnut Grove," near Clover Hill Pits, on the Summit, containing 110 acres, one-half cleared, well enclosed, and in a high state of cultivation, balance in wood of original growths!
On this farm is a comfortable dwelling- house with four rooms, and all necessary out-buildings, such as barn, dairy, stables, smoke- house, bath-house, &c. All the buildings are new.
On the same day will be sold all the perishable property on said estate, consisting of Horses, Cows, Sheep, Hogs, one Carriage, one Buggy, Household and Kitchen Furniture.
At the same time will be hired out for the balance of the year, three Negroes--two women and one man.

Terms of Sale--For the land, one-third cash; balance at 6 and 12 months, purchaser giving negotiable notes, interest added, title retained until last note is paid.
For all other property, cash on delivery.

div3.head: By James M. Taylor & Son., Aucts.
div3.p:
two Brick Houses and Lots, and one Vacant Lot Adjoining, on the North side of Broad Street, between Munford and Gilmer Streets, at Auction.--We will sell upon the premises, on Thursday, 10th day of April, commencing at 6 o'clock P. M. two very desirable brick Tenements, located as above.
They are adapted for small sized families, are commanding good rents, and are in fine order.

Also, two small framed Tenements in rear and a vacant Lot adjoining.
The lots are of the usual size.
Terms--One-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.--The purchaser to pay the taxes for 1862.

div3.head: Desirable Framed House and Lot on Federal street, in Sidney, at Auction.
div3.p:
--We will sell upon the premises, on Tuesday, the 8th day of April, commencing at 4 ½ o'clock P. M., the desirable framed House, on the north side of Elmwood, near to Grove street, now in the occupancy of A. B. Hall.
It contains several good rooms, Kitchen, &c., and adapted for a small-sized family; a well of water in the yard.
The Lot fronts 30 feet, and runs back 180 feet to an alley 20 feet wide.

Terms--One-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
The purchaser to pay the taxes for 1862.

Immediately after the above sale, will be sold a large lot of ground, on the north side of Westham Plank-road, fronting 170½ feet; and running back on the east line of Park street 178 feet, to an alley 20 feet wide.
It will be divided into lots of the usual front size.

Valuable land in the county of Chesterfield, nearly adjoining Manchester, at Auction. --The recent purchasers of the estate formerly owned by Charles H. Rhodes, Esq., finding that it contains more land than they wish to cultivate, we will sell, by request, on Tuesday, the 8th day of April, commencing at 1 o'clock, upon the premises, that portion thereof (with the exception of one lot) which lies between, and fronts upon, the River Road and the Manchester Turnpike, fronting the residence of Mr. A. C. Pulliam and others.

The land to be sold comprises 263 acres, embracing the Frog Level tract, with the dwelling thereon, and runs down to the Toll-gate at the upper end of Manchester.
The whole of this land lies beautifully for cultivation.
Some of it has been highly improved.
Some of it is fresh land, and the remainder is heavily set in woods.
Its elevated situation and nearness to Manchester, as well as to the very heart of Richmond, render this property highly valuable for cottage seats, market gardens, or for general agriculture.
It has been subdivided, according to a map which may be seen at our office, into lots ranging from 2 to 70 acres; thus affording to all an opportunity of gratifying their inclination as to quality.

Terms--One-third cash; the remainder at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by trust deeds.
The purchasers to pay the taxes for 1862.

div3.head: Most Valuable Brick Residence, on the North side of Main, between 1st and Adams streets, for Sale, and the Valuable private Residence at the North East Corner of Main and 1st streets, at Auction.
div3.p:
--We will sell upon the premises on Monday, the 21st day of April, commencing at 4 ½ o'clock P. M., the very valuable private Residence located on the North side of Main, between 1st and Foushee sts, now in the occupancy of R. H. Dibrell, Esq. It contains 11 large rooms, with closets, bath-house, hot and cold water, gas and water through the entire building, together with large Brick Kitchen, containing 4 rooms: also, a Brick Stable, Carriage-House, Smoke-House, and other buildings.
This house is admirably arranged for the accommodation of a larged sized family, and is in excellent order.
It is located in a very desirable neighborhood and convenient to business.
The lot fronts 35 feet and extends back 165 feet to a wide, paved alley.
--Also--

A valuable Building Lot adjoining on the East, having the same front and depth.
It is well set with the choicest Fruit Trees, Grapes, &c.

div4.p:
Immediately after the above, will be sold the large Brick Residence located at the Northeast intersection of Main and 1st streets, adjoining the residence of Theodrick Robertson, Esq., and now in the occupancy of Mr. Edwin Dibrell.
It contains about 10 rooms, and has attached a large Brick Kitchen.
The lot fronts about 70 feet and runs back 160 feet on 1st street.

Terms.--One-third cash; balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes; interest added, and secured by trust deeds.
Taxes and insurance for 1862 to be paid by purchaser or purchasers.

div3.head: Four Houses and Lots, and four Vacant Lots; on 17th and Marshall streets, at Auction.
div3.p: --We will sell, upon the premises, on Friday, the 11th day of April, commencing at 4 ½ o'clock P. M., four Houses and Lots, and four Vacant Lots adjoining, located as above.
1st. Two Brick Tenements on the west side of 17th, between Clay and Marshall streets, containing 5 comfortable rooms each, and now occupied by good tenants at fair rents.
Also, a vacant Lot at the corner of 17th and Marshall streets, fronting about 30 feet and running back 137 feet.
2nd. Two Framed Tenements on the South side of Clay, between 17th and 18th streets. The lots front 26 feet each and run back 166 feet.
Also, three vacant Lots immediately adjoining, fronting 25 feet and running back 166 feet each.
This property is desirable for residences or business stands, being contiguous to the Virginia Central Railroad Depot and the First Market, and adjoins the residence of Mr. Jno. Howard.

Terms.--One-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by trust deeds.
The purchaser to pay the taxes and insurance for 1862.

The Valuable Farm known as "Oakland," in the county of Henrico, lying on the Chickahominy river, 10 miles North of Richmond, on the Richmond, Fredericksburg and Potomac Railroad, for Sale at Auction.--The subscriber will sell, at public auction, on Wednesday, the 9th day of April, 1862, upon the premises, commencing at 12 o'clock M., that most valuable, fertile, and beautiful Farm known as "Oakland," containing about 550 acres, lying on the Chickahominy river, 10 miles North of the city of Richmond.
This farm presents many facilities that make it very desirable.
It is bounded on the west by the R., F. and P. Railroad, on the north and east by the Chickahominy river, on the South by the land of John B. Ryall and others.
The Richmond and Charlottesville plank-road runs through the tract, dividing the open from the wood land.
There are about 400 acres cleared, the balance heavily wooded.--This estate is under a high state of improvement and cultivation, and has been recently well manured and limed; well enclosed in five fields, with plank fence.
The buildings are large and spacious.
The dwelling is ample for the accommodation of a large family. --The barns, stables and out-houses are mostly new, and in good order; a well of excellent water in the yard; 8 or 10 never-failing springs on the place; besides being watered by the Chickahominy for a long distance.--Adjoining this estate there is a good grist and saw mill.
There are about 700 fruit trees of various kinds on the place.
It is proverbial for being healthy, and the neighborhood is excellent.
It has a turn-out, and adjoining is a smith's shop.
To appreciate this estate it is only necessary to view it, and those who may desire to do so are invited to examine the premises.
My son, residing on the farm, will take pleasure in showing it. I offer this valuable estate for no other reason than that my business engagements in the city require my whole time and attention.

Terms.--One-fourth cash; the remainder at 1, 2 and 3 years, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
The taxes and insurance for 1862 to be paid by the purchaser.
div3.closer:
William Taylor.
P. S.--The property can be treated for privately.
Jas. M. Taylor & Son, Aucts. mh 26

div3.head: One hundred and Twenty beautiful Building Lots contiguous to the city of Richmond, at Auction.
div3.p:
--We will sell, upon the premises, on Tuesday, the 8th day of April, commencing at 4 o'clock P. M., 120 beautiful building Lots, lying east of, and contiguous to, the city of Richmond, on the road from 17th street to the Mechanicsville Turnpike, and from any portion of which there is a fine view of the city.
This sale presents a rare opportunity for a profitable investment, as well as to persons desiring lots for building purposes.

Persons desiring to purchase, are respectfully asked to view the property before the day of sale, a plat of which may be seen at the office of the auctioneers.
If desired, the property will be sold in squares or lots.
Terms.--One half cash; the balance at 6, and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, secured by trust deeds.

div3.head: Also
div3.p: --A beautiful suburban Lot, of the 123 lots on Barton Hill advertised by us for sale on Tuesday, 9th April, is one of five acres, rich with a beautiful elevation and view of Richmond, on the end of 17th street, having a grove of cedar trees on the road leading to Mechanicsville Turnpike, running back to a spring branch of pure water, making a very desirable growing lot or market garden.

div3.head: By Jas. M. Taylor & Son, Auctioneers.
div3.p:
Valuable Real estate, on 5TH Street, Navy Hill, at Auction.--We will sell upon the premises, Wednesday, the 9th day of April, commencing at 4½ o'clock P. M., two lots of ground on Navy Hill, in the city of Richmond, designated as Nos 59 and 60, fronting together 60 feet on the West line of 5th street and running back within parallel lines 122 feet to an alley in common, sixteen feet wide.
The improvements thereon are a large, comfortable Framed Dwelling, containing 9 good rooms, with fireplaces in 8 of them, together with a two-story kitchen and other out-buildings; also, a well of excellent water upon the premises.

Terms.--One-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
The taxes and insurance for 1862 to be paid by the purchaser.

div3.head: One of the most desirable business stands, on the North side of Cary, between 13th and 14th streets, for Sale at Auction.
div3.p:
--We will sell on Tuesday, the 8th day of April, 1862, commencing at 12 o'clock M., that most desirable business stand, at the corner of Cary and Virginia streets, on the North side of Cary street, fronting 30 feet on Cary street and running back to an alley.
The house has been recently built, with granite front, four stories, besides cellar.
This property is justly regarded the most valuable in market, from its contiguity to the various depots and business portion of the city.

Terms.--One-third cash; the remainder at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, secured by trust deed.
Taxes and insurance for 1862 to be paid by the purchaser.

div3.head: A Valuable business stand on Brook Avenue, near to Broad street, at Auction.
div3.p:
--We will sell upon the premises, on Thursday, the 10th day of April, commencing at 4 ½ o'clock P. M., the valuable three story Brick House, on the east side of Brook Avenue, near to Broad street, and now in the occupancy of Dr. Dillard.
It is adapted for any mercantile business, and has ample accommodations above for a large family; is supplied with gas and water, and is in perfect order, having been recently erected.
The lot has the usual front and depth, and runs back to a wide alley.

Terms.--One-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
The purchaser to pay the taxes and insurance for 1862.

div3.head:
By Thos. W. Keesee, Auct'r,
(Office corner of Cary and 12th streets.)
div3.p: Auction Sale of Elegant House Hold and Kitchen Furniture I will sell on Tuesday, the 15th day of April, commencing at 10 o'clock, A. M., at the residence on the north side of Grace between 3d and 4th streets, the entire Furniture contained therein, consisting of an excellent assortment of Parlor, Chamber, and Dining-room Furniture, splendid mirror, &c., and the usual Kitchen Furniture, including a large Cooking Stove.
Terms--Cash on delivery.

div3.head: Very Valuable Farm, corn, fodder, shucks, Cows, Hogs, horse cart, farming implements, &c., for Sale at Auction.
div3.p:
--At the request of R. H. Hundley, Esq., I will sell, on the premises, on Monday, the 14th of April, commencing at 11 o'clock, his very valuable Farm in Hanover county, three miles from Ashland, adjoining the lands of E. M. Tompkins and others.
The farm contains 163 acres; thirty acres of meadow, in a high state of cultivation, a portion of which is seeded in wheat and oats.
There is a fine young orchard; fine well of water; the buildings, framed dwelling nearly new, out-houses ample; 50 barrels of corn, 9 stacks of blade fodder, top fodder, shucks, four cows, hogs, fine work horse, cart, farming implements, &c.

Terms--The perishable property will be sold for cash.
For the farm, the terms will be very liberal.

div3.head: By Richard Cauthorn, Auct'r.
div3.p: Stock of fine Ready made Clothing, Merchant Tailoring Goods, &c., at Auction.--On Tuesday, 8th inst., at 10 o'clock, at the Store of Mark Nelson, on Broad, between 4th and 5th streets, I will sell at auction, for cash, his entire stock of--
Ready-Made Clothing,
Merchant Tailoring Goods,
Piece Goods,
Cravats, Summer Clothing, &c.
All of the very best quality.

div3.head: Receiver's Sale.
div3.p: --In pursuance of a decree of the Confederate States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia, I shall, on Friday, the 18th inst., (if fair; if not, the next fair day,) proceed to sell, on the premises, at public auction, to the highest bidder, the tract of land lying in the county of Louisa, about 1½ miles from Tolersville, known as the "Slate Hill Gold Mining Tract," and containing 81 acres and 40 poles.

I shall at the same time sell all the personal property upon said land, consisting of one 120 horse power Steam Engine, one small 7 horse power Steam Engine, one ⅜ Whim Chain 280 feet long, one Sheet-Iron Dolly Lub, one 4-inch Rope, weighing about one ton, and many other articles.

Terms of Sale--For the Land, one-third of the purchase money to be paid in cash; the balance in two equal instalments at 6 and 12 months, with interest from the day of sale, the title to be withheld until the last payment is made.
For the personal property, cash will be required.
div3.closer:
Henry L. Brooke,
Receiver District No. 3. ap 4--td

div3.head: Receiver's Sale of stocks.
div3.p: Will be sold at our office on Tuesday next, the 8th of April, at 12 o'clock M., three hundred and eighteen.
div3.closer:
Shares
of Bank of Virginia Stock, on account of H. L. Brooke, Receiver.
Jno. A. Lancaster & Son. ap 1--td

div3.head: For Rent
div3.p:
--A Brick House with six rooms and all requisite out-buildings, on 2d, near Marshall street. The whole premises are in excellent condition, having been thoroughly repaired, papered, and painted since it was occupied.
Apply to
div3.closer:
Smith & Harwood,
No. 85 Main street. ap 5--2t

div3.head: For Rent — a large Dwelling well furnished.
div3.p:
--At the request of the present tenant we are authorized to Rent, for three or ten months, the large and handsomely located Residence on the west side of 6th, near to Leigh street, recently occupied by Col. Edm.
Fontaine, together with all the Furniture therein, of superior quality.
Apply to

div3.head: Four acres of beautiful land in Sidney, opposite to the Sidney Baptist Church, for Sale.
div3.p:
--The beautiful square of four acres, in Sidney, located as above, with two Brick Tenements thereon, in a high state of cultivation, now occupied by Mr. Belling, is for sale.
Apply to

div3.head: For Rent
div3.p: --A furnished House.
Apply on Broad street,
Next door to the African Church.

Terms moderate.
ap 4--6t*

div3.head: For Rent
div3.p:
--A House situated on 25th street, Union Hill, containing five or six rooms, and in good order.
Possession had immediately.
For terms, &c., apply to
div3.closer:
Clopton & Lyne, Agents
For Renting out Houses, &c. ap 4--tm

div3.head: For Rent.
div3.p:
--The large Tobacco Factory, next to Mayo's Warehouse, on the dock.
For further particulars apply at Mayo's Warehouse, or to

div3.head: For Rent
div3.p:
--The Office now occupied by us, under St. Charles Hotel.
Possession given about 1st April.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--The books and accounts of the late firm of Davis & Hutcheson will be found at the office of Messrs. Wm.
E. leance & Co. All persons having claims against the firm will present them at that office for set lament.
Those indebted will call and make payment without delay.
Mr. Wm. B. Isaacs is duly authorized to make all settlements and grant receipt.
div3.closer:
John R. Davis,
Surviving Partner of Davis & Hutcheson. mh 31--1m

div3.p:
Miles Cary, Forwarding and Commission Merchant, south side of Cary street, between 13th or Governor and Virginia.--Having taken the office, &c., of Wm.
G. Miller, who has gone in the army, I shall carry on exclusively a General Forwarding and Commission business.
The patronage of my friends and the public, also Mr. Miller's former patrons, is solicited.

div3.head:
Office soldiers' aid
Richmond April 1, 1862.
div3.p: To the Richmond Volunteers, Commandants of companies raised in this city, where are enlisted for the war, will please send a perfect list of their respective companies, with place of residence of each member, to this office, without delay, in order that aid may be properly dispensed to their wives and children.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--All members of Capts in Woolfolk's Battery absent on furlough, &c., in the city of Richmond and vicinity, will report to me at the depot of the Central Railroad, in this city, on Tuesday morning, the 8th inst., between the hours of six and seven o'clock, in order to return to their company.
Such as may be in the county of Hanover will report to me on the arrival of the at Atlee's Station or the Court-House.
Those who fail to report as above will be immediately advertised and treated as deserters.

div3.head: $30 reward.
div3.p: --I will give the above reward for the apprehension and delivery to me, in this Camp, of Francis D. Atwell, a deserter from my company.
div3.closer:
W. R. Berkelly,
Capt Comd'g Co. K, 21st Va., Regt.,
Camp near Mr. Jackson. ap 5--3t*

div3.head:
Bivouac, near Orange C. H.,
March 22d, 1862.
div3.p: Deserted from the camp near Centreville, on or about the 2nd day of March, 1862, James E. Robinson, a private in Company I, 1st Regt. Va. Volunteers.

The said J. E. Robinson is about 20 years old, five feet seven inches high, auburn hair, gray eyes, light complexion, and when enlisted was an apprentice to John H. Glazebrook, carpenter.
He is well known about Baker street, Richmond.

div3.head:
Maryland men,
attention!
div3.p: We are manufacturing, and have on hand, a lot of Maryland Badges, which will have to be closed out in two weeks. All those in want of the same will please call early, or address.
div3.closer:
Lewis & Kayton.
13th, betw. Main and Cary sts., Richmond, Va.
Price, 50 cents a piece, by mail 55 cents. ap 4--1w*

div3.head: Substitute.
div3.p: A most desirable
Substitute
Can be heard of by addressing
div3.closer:
"Josephus."
At this office. ap 4--3t*

div3.head: Wise Zouaves.
div3.p:
The undersigned is enlisting a company of Infantry for the 20th Regiment Virginia Volunteers, to be called the Wise Zouaves, in compliment of the memory of the late Captain Wise.
This company will be instructed by Mr. C. F. Pardigon in the Zouave drill of the French Infantry, and taught by him the bayonet exercise.
Being familiar in all its detail, and having aided Captain Carr in the translation of the French works on Bayonet Exercise, his ability to instruct in that drill cannot be questioned.

Militiamen desiring to enter this service will apply to the undersigned, on 12th street, one door above Main.
The usual bounty of $50 will be paid the men when mustered into the Confederate service.

div3.head:
Adj't & Insp. General's Office.
Richmond, March 29th, 1862.
special Orders, no. 72.
[extract.]
div3.p:
XXIX.
Army Regulations, published under authority from the War Department, are now on sale by the publisher, J. W. Randolph, Richmond, Va., at $1.50, price determined upon by the authorities.
Officers of the Army are thus informed, to enable them to purchase, and acquaint themselves with the requirements of the service.
div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
John Withers,
Assistant Adj't General. mh 3t--6t

div3.head:
$50 bounty.--
Crescent Zouaves battalion.
Wanted
div3.p:
--Recruits to fill up the battalion of Crescent Zouaves, under the command of Major W. Hyllested.
A bounty of fifty dollars will be paid each recruit upon enlistment.
A neat uniform of gray cloth, Zouave style, will be furnished.

This corps will be one of the best organized and equipped in the service, and its commander having had many years' military experience, both in this and foreign countries, will make it a battalion worthy of the admiration of his commanding General, and one that young men will be proud to serve in. Those wishing to enlist will apply to
div3.closer:
Capt. Wm. T. Fry,
Recruiting Officer,
No. 5 Exchange Block,
Under Exchange Hotel. ap 1--2w*

div3.head: $25 reward
div3.p:
--Ranaway from my store, on Tuesday morning, 15th instant, my negro Boy, Lewis Washington.
He is a bright mulatto, thick set, about 5 feet high, 15 years old; had on when last seen a brown sack coat, brown pants, and a military cap. The above reward will be paid for his delivery to me.
div3.closer:
S. S. Cottrell,
No. 129 Main street. ap 2--ts

div3.head: $15 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from my residence, in Ashland, Hanover county, Va., on Thursday, 20th March, my servant woman, named Fanny; about 20 years old; low in stature; ginger-bread color; rather long hair, and when spoken to has a pleasant look.
I purchased her from O. Cranz, trustee, in this city, last fall.
She may be lurking about the city.
I will pay the above reward of $15 if apprehended and delivered to me in Ashland, or lodged in some jail, that I may procure her.
div3.closer: Hiram James, Ashland. ap 1--6t*

div3.p: --Merchants and others receiving freight via Richmond and Petersburg Railroad Company are hereby notified if goods are not taken away in twenty four hours after their arrival, they will be stored at their expense and risk.

div3.head:
For Sale--
a Soap and
Candle Factory,
div3.p:
located in Manchester.
A rare chance for a good investment.
Apply at the Factory, Main street, near Engine-House, Manchester.

div3.head: Green Spring land for Sale.
div3.p:
I offer for sale privately my Farm, containing 278 acres, lying seven miles south of Trevillian Depot, Central Railroad, with everything necessary for immediate occupation and cultivation, including Provisions, Stock, Furniture, &c., &c. The land is highly improved--three fields in grass, one in wheat, and one ready for corn.
The buildings are new and excellent.
The dwelling a handsome cottage, with eightrooms, and is of the best material and workmanship.
For particulars, apply to Wm. S. Royster, corner of Virginia and Cary streets.
Address

Farm of 40 acres of land, on New Road, near the Fair Grounds, for sale.
We are authorized to sell the valuable Farm, (in rear of the farm recently owned by Robert A. Lancaster, Esq.,) containing 40 acres within three hundred yards of the new Fair Grounds.
There has recently been erected on it a new dwelling and an excellent barn.
This is really a beautiful location for a suburban residence.
Apply to us.
Terms--Accommodating.

Very beautiful Building Lot, on the east line of 3d, between Cary and Canal streets, for sale. --We are authorized to sell that most beautiful lot located as above, adjoining the residence of Mrs. C. S. Morgan.
The lot has a front of 32¾ feet, and a depth of 140 feet to an alley 10 feet wide.--this is truly a most beautiful lot in every respect.
Apply to

div3.head: For Sale
div3.p:
--My Farm, containing 100 acres; 80 of which are cleared, the remainder in wood, eight miles below the city, on the Central road.
The buildings consist of a large framed Dwelling, four rooms, two brick chimneys; Barn; Stable, and a well of good water in the yard.
Those wishing to purchase will call on.

div3.head: The beautiful Farm of 139 acres, called "West view," on the Westham Plank-Road, 4½ miles West of Richmond, for Sale.
div3.p:
--We are authorized to sell the very valuable Farm located as above, now in the occupancy of Mr. Edward McCounell.
This is probably the most desirable farm of its size now in market, as the land is not only naturally of fine foundation, but has been greatly improved by fertilizers.
The buildings on the place are all in good order, having been built within the last ten years, and are ample for the accommodation of a large family.--The place so well known that a minute description is deemed unnecessary.
Persons disposition invest their funds in land in the most improving neighborhood, are particularly invited to examine this estate.
Terms reasonable.
Apply to

div3.head:
Farm in Georgia
for Sale.
div3.p:
In the Blue Limestone section, northwest part of the State; 150 acres cleared; whole tract acres; good brick dwelling; dark brown poplar and hickory growth; $20 per acre.
at interest to suit purchaser, or young negroe at value, or Confederate bonds at par, taken in payment.
Address

div3.head: For Sale
div3.p:
--Privately, a number of Lots in Sidney, on Grace and Broad streets, just beyond the corporation line.
Also in Manchester, Houses and Lots, on street.
One has attached to it a rich and productive garden.
The basement rooms be used as stores.
And for rent or lease, Lots; both in Richmond and Manchester.
Apply to
div3.closer:
Dr. Broocks,
Corner Main and 12th streets
Office hours, from 8 to 9 A. M., and from 3 to 4 o'clock P. M. ap 1--1m*

div3.head: Very beautiful and well located private Dwelling, on the South side of Marshall, between 10th and 11th streets, for Sale.
div3.p:
--At the request of Mr. W. A. Armistead, [who is about to remove to the country.] we are authorized to sell this valuable private Dwelling, located as above.
This dwelling was built about three years ago, and no expense spared to make it complete in every respect.
It has 10 rooms, besides kitchen of 6 rooms, large stable and carriage-house, with servants' room above.
There are marble mantels in six rooms, gas, hot and cold water, city culverts for drainage, cooking range, and every modern improvement usually found in a first-class dwelling.
It has an iron verandah and marble steps in front, and two-story portico in the rear, and the house is heated with furnaces.
The lot has a front of 36 feet and a depth of 150 feet to a wide, paved alley.
Altogether, this is among the most desirable residence in Richmond.
Apply to

div3.head: Valuable Farm of 260 acres in Hanover county, near to Goodall's Tavern, and five miles from Ashland, for Sale.
div3.p:
--We are authorized to sell the above valuable Farm.
It is situated about five miles from Ashland, contains 260 acres land, about 50 acres cleared, balance wood land — oak, hickory, and pine, which will make excellent rail timberland fire-wood.
There is on the place a dwelling-house, nearly new, containing eight rooms, and is a most excellent house, with a some two-story porch in front.
The house is in a beautiful grove of oaks, with good enclosure, and a well of excellent water in the yard.
It is one of the healthiest places in the State; has on it an excellent frame kitchen, with four rooms; also, a good smoke-house and dairy, and a large barn and stables.

This is really a most desirable place, and its nearness to Ashland makes it accessible to Richmond two or three times daily.
The neighborhood is one of the best in this section.
It is sixteen miles distant from Richmond, with the Brook turnpike leading to Richmond, thus having advantages of railroad and turnpike.
This place was improved, and is occupied by Captain P. Woolfolk, Jr. of the Ashland Artillery.
His family are now living there and will take pleasure in showing the place.
Possession given immediately.
Terms--One-third cash, one third at twelve months, and one- third at 24 months. Interest to be added and title retained until the last payment is made.

div3.head: Spring is coming
div3.p: --I respectfully call the attention of the ladies to the fact that I have lately enlarged my stock and assortment of goods, among which are Roches; Bonnet Silks, plain and checked; Illusions, black and white; and a large assortment of Velvet and Bonnet Ribbons, together with a number of articles not strictly in the Millinery line; all of which can be seen at No. 209 Broad street.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--In consequence of having no assistance in my business, and having to pay cash for all my purchases.
I am compelled to sell exclusively for cash from this date.
Purchasers will please bear this in mind, and let the cash accompany their orders.

div3.p:
We shall order our entire Stock of Goods at cost, for cash, until the 15th April, as we are determined to close business.
Call at once, if want bargains in China, Glass, and Earthenware.

div3.head: Academy — Guiney S. C., Caroline Co., Va.
div3.p:
--This list class Institution, thoroughly preparatory to the University of Va., and also for the Engineering profession, whether Civil or Military, can receive a few more pupils.
--from March 1st to close of Session, for everything except lights.
Address or information the Principal.

div3.head: Manchester Hotel.
div3.p: Within 400 yards of the Manchester station, on the Richmond and Danville Railroad, and 20 minutes walk of all the Public Offices, Depots, and Landings in Richmond.

Attached to the Hotel is a large stable and carriage-house, attended by a reliable celler.
A trial of this house by the traveling public is respectfully solicited.
div3.closer:
B. J. Sizes
Manchester, Va., March, 1862. mh --12t*

div3.head:
Executive Department,
Richmond, Va., March 7, 1862.
div3.p:
all Sheriffs and others collecting State Arms are desired to have the same boxed, marked "Col. C. Dimmock, Richmond, Va.," and forwarded as soon as possible.
The compensation for collecting and the necessary expenses of transportation to this city, will be paid on the presentation of the receipts of Col. Dimmock.
Approved,
div3.closer:
John Letcher.
